entry.content: Our upstream provider resolved the networking issues causing intermittent failures and connectivity has returned to normal. entry.title: Resolved: Issues with US region availability and application builds
entry.content:
Between April 18th 02:07 UTC and 02:21 UTC a database failed which caused some applications to receive H99 errors and builds to time out. We apologize for the issues this incident caused. The root cause of this issue was a database failure.Even though the automated failover worked as expected, it did take longer than intended.

We are in the process of modifying our operational procedures for this system to enable a more timely failover response. This will prevent your application from receiving H99 errors during this type of database failure.

A separate issue in how we detect when builds fail was identified as a result of the initial database failure. During the database failure builds were taking one hour to fail as they were waiting for a timeout condition. We are completing a change to our build system to better detect this failure and mark builds as failed earlier in the build lifecycle.

entry.title: Resolved: Recurrence of increased latency and errors in EU region
entry.content:
On March 22nd between 13:51 UTC and 14:32 UTC, and once again between 15:41 UTC and 16:12 UTC, customers in the EU region on the Common Runtime may have experienced higher latencies and some failing HTTP requests, both for incoming and outgoing traffic. We accept full responsibility for any downtime arising from this issue and apologize for negative effects our customers experienced.

Here is some additional detail about what happened and steps we are taking to mitigate future outages of a similar nature.

Who was affected?

Over the course of the two incidents, some apps running in the EU region had one or more dynos impacted. These dynos would have seen traffic degradation for parts or the entirety of the event.

What Happened?

The Heroku platform was used by a few abusive applications sending floods of UDP packets to remote targets. The high number of packets flooded the network of the underlying server, impacting other dynos running on the same underlying server and affecting their response times.

Our monitoring applications were also impaired, making the events look like network instability or more general network issues, slowing our ability to identify the problem in a timely manner.

What did we do to prevent wider impact?

Once identified, the abusive applications were removed from the platform by our security team.

What will we do to mitigate problems like this in the future?

We are going to increase the sensitivity of network monitoring tools to shorten the time it takes to detect such events when they take place and will provide better documentation for our first line responders in order to identify and take action against this kind of platform abuse more rapidly.

The ongoing work of our abuse detection team will also help thwart other similar attempts before they have any impact on the platform.
